reviewText: I just caught this movie by accident on Turner Classic Movies. I turned on the home theater and it was tuned to TCM from the night before. They were near the end of a short tribute to their star of the month (Dec. 2012) Barbara Stanwyck which I had seen before, so I waited to see what they were showing next. When Ben Mankiewicz began his introduction to the movie I was intrigued, since I always thought RIDE THE HIGH COUNTRY was Sam Peckinpah's (THE WILD BUNCH,CROSS OF IRON) first film. After watching and enjoying the movie, which I enjoyed greatly and would give 3 1/2 stars, I looked for a DVD. According to most reviews there is no decent release available at this time (except for a German import), and being spoiled from just viewing TCM's gorgeous undamaged Panavision and Pathe Color print (which might hint at a planned future "official" release), I will delay a detailed review for a later date. I do, however want to explain my review title, and the inspiration behind it. SMALL SPOILER ALERT AHEAD! In the beginning of the film, Brian Keith (REFLECTIONS IN A GOLDEN EYE) walks into a saloon, a finds a man (Chill Wills (GIANT,THE ALAMO) in a atypical evil and, sorry, chilling role) hanging from a noose and precariously balanced on a small whiskey keg. The members of a card game explain that Chill is a card cheat, but Brian notices a scar on his wrist and begins to forcibly save him, which happens, but in a rather unexpected way. Soon after, Brian, Chill and now Steve Cochran (WHITE HEAT) are riding into Gila City, and we're shown a wide shot of the town's main street, lined by buildings and busy with the hustle and bustle of everyday life, including a group of kids playing in the dusty thoroughfare. Brian is then distracted by a poignant harmonica, and the point-of-view shot moves to the upper right and we see a kid about the same age as the ruffians below, but standing on a building's roof dressed in a suit alone playing the harmonica. Now if you're familiar with Charles Bronson's (HARD TIMES,DEATH HUNT) slowly lengthening flashbacks in Sergio Leone's western masterpiece ONCE UPON A TIME IN THE WEST you'll understand what I mean. If not, what are you waiting for?
